Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Lymphedema Intervention Exercise for Breast Cancer Survivors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is its benefit for millions of individuals who are at risk for or have developed chronic lymphedema, including patients who have been treated for breast cancer and other cancers (head and neck, prostate, melanoma, gynaecological cancer). Lymphedema is a progressive and chronic swelling with many distressful symptoms after cancer treatment. Each year, 1.38 million women worldwide and more than 230,000 women in the US are diagnosed with breast cancer. At least 20-40% of breast cancer survivors have developed lymphedema and the rest of them are at lifelong risk for lymphedema. This project further develops a lymphatic therapy effective in reducing the risk of lymphedema and relieving lymphedema symptoms for breast cancer survivors. The approach may potentially be applied more broadly to individuals with chronic heart failure, end-stage renal disease and hypertension with similar abnormal fluid accumulation symptoms.

This I-Corps project explores the commercial potential of a lymphatic therapy. The core technology consists of a physical therapy system that can automatically and accurately track a patient's movement and evaluate it against the desired movement. The system provides instant feedback on whether a patient is performing an exercise correctly and how should the patient make adjustments in their movement. Furthermore, the system will be designed to motivate the patient to perform the therapy correctly and regularly. The system will leverage the novel computer vision and machine learning algorithms being developed in an on-going research project in order to overcome the sensor constraints in detecting joint positions and the significant variability of the normal range of the desired movement, which are the major technical obstacles faced by current sensor-based physical therapy systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lymphedema is a progressive and chronic accumulation of lymph fluid in the interstitial spaces of the affected limb and areas, leading to abnormal swelling and other distressing symptoms. Lymphedema is one of the most distressing and feared late adverse effects from cancer treatment that usually occurs 1 to 5 years after cancer treatment. Without timely intervention in the early disease stage, lymphedema can progress into a chronic condition that no surgical or medical interventions at present can cure, causing the poor quality of life of breast cancer survivors. It remains a major health concern which has affected more than 40% of 3.1 million breast cancer survivors in US. 

In a current NIH funded project jointly lead by Co-PIs Wang and Fu, the team is developing a prototype Kinect-enhanced intervention training system, to teach surviviors of breast cancer surgery to perform lymphatic exercises effectively, to reduce the risk for breast cancer related lymphedema. The PIs would like to explore the possibility of translating the developed technologies into a Kinect-based ExerGame (called ExerLymph)  that patients can play at home, to motivate the patients to perform the lymphatic exercise regularly and correctly. Such a game is expected to have wide appeal to all breast cancer patients post surgery and the cost is expected to be borne by the insurance provider. The goal of the I-Corps project is for the project team to learn the customer discovery and business planning process and conduct interviews with potential customers, to assess the busineess potential of the ExerLymph system.

The entire team attended the training and closing meetings for the I-corps teams in March and May 2017, respectively. The team learnt about customer discovery and business planning. The team conducted many interviews in both hospital clinics and physical therapy providers, to learn about the pain points in physical therary, the patient population (general PT vs. patients with lymphedema), and the ecosystem involving physical therapy.

The I-corps project provided useful training to the entire team regarding the customer discovery and business planning. This is an eye-opening experience for the academic PIs. The project also provided invaluable business training for the Entrprenure Lead (EL), who was an engineering graduent studeent. The EL also improved significantly in his communications skills.

The I-Corps project provided invaluable business training for the two PIs and the EL. Such training is not only extremely helpful for potential future endeavor of the PIs to bring their technology to products, but also informs their future research efforts. The project had transformative impact on the EL in terms of his communication and business skills. 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2018
Modified by: Yao Wang
